content:
MouseEventArgs Class

In this Article

Provides data for mouse related routed events that do not specifically involve mouse buttons or the mouse wheel, for example MouseMove.

Syntax

Declaration

public class MouseEventArgs : System.Windows.Input.InputEventArgs

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • Object
  • EventArgs
  • RoutedEventArgs
  • System.Windows.Input.InputEventArgs
  • MouseEventArgs

Inherited Members

Empty
,

,

,

Remarks

This event data class is used with the following attached events.

  • <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.GotMouseCapture?displayProperty=fullName>
  • <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.LostMouseCapture?displayProperty=fullName>
  • <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseEnter?displayProperty=fullName>
  • <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseLeave?displayProperty=fullName>
  • <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseMove?displayProperty=fullName>
  • <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.PreviewMouseMove?displayProperty=fullName>

    This event data class is used with the following routed events. These routed events forward the previously listed attached events to make them more accessible to the general element model in WPF.

  • System.Windows.UIElement.MouseEnter
  • System.Windows.UIElement.MouseLeave
  • System.Windows.UIElement.MouseMove
  • System.Windows.UIElement.PreviewMouseMove
  • System.Windows.ContentElement.MouseEnter
  • System.Windows.ContentElement.MouseLeave
  • System.Windows.ContentElement.MouseMove
  • System.Windows.ContentElement.PreviewMouseMove

    The attached events and the base element routed events share their event data, and the bubbling and tunneling versions of the routed events also share event data. This can affect the handled characteristics of the event as it travels the event route. For details, see Input Overview.

    Other than the RoutedEventArgs properties that are relevant for all routed events, the most interesting properties of MouseEventArgs that you might use in a MouseEventHandler implementation are several properties that expose the current button state (such as LeftButton) and MouseDevice). MouseDevice is useful particularly because you can check Captured on it.

    Note that events that specifically deal with mouse button events use a different event data class, MouseButtonEventArgs. The mouse button properties are available on MouseEventArgs in case there are input modes or interactions that involve the buttons even if you are handling a non-button event.

    The Mouse class provides additional properties and methods for determining the state of the mouse.

Constructors summary

MouseEventArgs(MouseDevice,Int32)

Initializes a new instance of the MouseEventArgs class using the specified MouseDevice and timestamp
MouseEventArgs(MouseDevice,Int32,StylusDevice)

Initializes a new instance of the MouseEventArgs class using the specified MouseDevice, timestamp, and StylusDevice.

Properties summary

LeftButton

Gets the current state of the left mouse button.
MiddleButton

Gets the current state of the middle mouse button.
MouseDevice

Gets the mouse device associated with this event.
RightButton

Gets the current state of the right mouse button.
StylusDevice

Gets the stylus device associated with this event.
XButton1

Gets the current state of the first extended mouse button.
XButton2

Gets the state of the second extended mouse button.

Methods summary

GetPosition(IInputElement)

Returns the position of the mouse pointer relative to the specified element.
InvokeEventHandler(Delegate,Object)

Invokes event handlers in a type-specific way, which can increase event system efficiency.

Constructors

  • MouseEventArgs(MouseDevice,Int32)

    Initializes a new instance of the MouseEventArgs class using the specified MouseDevice and timestamp

    public MouseEventArgs (System.Windows.Input.MouseDevice mouse, int timestamp);

    Parameters

    • mouse
      MouseDevice

      The mouse device associated with this event.

    • timestamp
      Int32

      The time when the input occurred.

  • MouseEventArgs(MouseDevice,Int32,StylusDevice)

    Initializes a new instance of the MouseEventArgs class using the specified MouseDevice, timestamp, and StylusDevice.

    public MouseEventArgs (System.Windows.Input.MouseDevice mouse, int timestamp, System.Windows.Input.StylusDevice stylusDevice);

    Parameters

    • mouse
      MouseDevice

      The mouse device associated with this event.

    • timestamp
      Int32

      The time when the input occurred.

    • stylusDevice
      StylusDevice

      The logical stylus device associated with this event.

Properties

  • LeftButton

    Gets the current state of the left mouse button.

    public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState LeftButton { get; }

    Property Value

    • MouseButtonState

      The current state of the left mouse button, which is either MouseButtonState or MouseButtonState. There is no default value.

    Remarks

    The Mouse class provides additional properties and methods for determining the state of the mouse.

    Example

    The following example prints a message if the state of the LeftButton property is MouseButtonState. 

    If e.LeftButton = MouseButtonState.Pressed Then
    MessageBox.Show("The Left Mouse Button is pressed")
End If

    if (e.LeftButton == MouseButtonState.Pressed)
{
    MessageBox.Show("The Left Mouse Button is pressed");
}
  • MiddleButton

    Gets the current state of the middle mouse button.

    public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState MiddleButton { get; }

    Property Value

    • MouseButtonState

      The current state of the middle mouse button, which is either MouseButtonState or MouseButtonState. There is no default value.

    Remarks

    The Mouse class provides additional properties and methods for determining the state of the mouse.

    Example

    The following example prints a message if the state of the MiddleButton property is MouseButtonState. 

    If e.MiddleButton = MouseButtonState.Pressed Then

    MessageBox.Show("The Middle Mouse Button is pressed")
End If

    if (e.MiddleButton == MouseButtonState.Pressed)
{

    MessageBox.Show("The Middle Mouse Button is pressed");
}
  • MouseDevice

    Gets the mouse device associated with this event.

    public System.Windows.Input.MouseDevice MouseDevice { get; }

    Property Value

    • MouseDevice

      The mouse device associated with this event. There is no default value.

    Remarks

    The Mouse class provides additional properties and methods for determining the state of the mouse.

    Example

    The following example gets the MouseDevice associated with an input event. 

    Dim mouseDevice As MouseDevice = e.MouseDevice

    MouseDevice mouseDevice = e.MouseDevice;
  • RightButton

    Gets the current state of the right mouse button.

    public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState RightButton { get; }

    Property Value

    • MouseButtonState

      The current state of the right mouse button, which is either MouseButtonState or MouseButtonState. There is no default value.

    Remarks

    The Mouse class provides additional properties and methods for determining the state of the mouse.

    Example

    The following example prints a message if the state of the RightButton property is MouseButtonState. 

    If e.RightButton = MouseButtonState.Pressed Then
    MessageBox.Show("The Right Mouse Button is pressed")
End If

    if (e.RightButton == MouseButtonState.Pressed)
{
    MessageBox.Show("The Right Mouse Button is pressed");
}
  • StylusDevice

    Gets the stylus device associated with this event.

    public System.Windows.Input.StylusDevice StylusDevice { get; }

    Property Value

    • StylusDevice

      The stylus associated with this event. There is no default value.

    Example

    The following example shows how to retrieve the StylusDevice associated with an event. 

    Dim stylusDevice As StylusDevice = e.StylusDevice

    StylusDevice stylusDevice = e.StylusDevice;
  • XButton1

    Gets the current state of the first extended mouse button.

    public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState XButton1 { get; }

    Property Value

    • MouseButtonState

      The current state of the first extended mouse button, which is either MouseButtonState or MouseButtonState. There is no default value.

    Remarks

    The Mouse class provides additional properties and methods for determining the state of the mouse.

    Example

    The following example prints a message if the state of the XButton1 property is MouseButtonState. 

    If e.XButton1 = MouseButtonState.Pressed Then
    MessageBox.Show("The XButton1 Mouse Button is pressed")
End If

    if (e.XButton1 == MouseButtonState.Pressed)
{
    MessageBox.Show("The XButton1 Mouse Button is pressed");
}
  • XButton2

    Gets the state of the second extended mouse button.

    public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState XButton2 { get; }

    Property Value

    • MouseButtonState

      The current state of the second extended mouse button, which is either MouseButtonState or MouseButtonState. There is no default value.

    Remarks

    The Mouse class provides additional properties and methods for determining the state of the mouse.

    Example

    The following example prints a message if the state of the XButton2 property is MouseButtonState. 

    If e.XButton2 = MouseButtonState.Pressed Then
    MessageBox.Show("The XButton2 Mouse Button is pressed")
End If

    if (e.XButton2 == MouseButtonState.Pressed)
{
    MessageBox.Show("The XButton2 Mouse Button is pressed");
}

Methods

  • GetPosition(IInputElement)

    Returns the position of the mouse pointer relative to the specified element.

    public System.Windows.Point GetPosition (System.Windows.IInputElement relativeTo);

    Parameters

    • relativeTo
      IInputElement

      The element to use as the frame of reference for calculating the position of the mouse pointer.

    Returns

    • Point

      The x- and y-coordinates of the mouse pointer position relative to the specified object.

    Remarks

    The point (0,0) is the upper-left corner of the frame of reference.

    The static GetPosition method can also be used to obtain the position of the mouse.

  • InvokeEventHandler(Delegate,Object)

    Invokes event handlers in a type-specific way, which can increase event system efficiency.

    protected override void InvokeEventHandler (Delegate genericHandler, object genericTarget);

    Parameters

    • genericHandler
      Delegate

      The generic handler to call in a type-specific way.

    • genericTarget
      Object

      The target to call the handler on.

    Remarks

    This implementation casts the generic handler as a MouseEventHandler and then invokes it. For details on this implementation pattern and the reasons for it, see InvokeEventHandler and Routed Events Overview.
